title: The Nebraskan Who Rules the Scottish Highland Games
text:
Chuck Kasson has startled more than a few cyclists while practicing the hammer toss near a bike trail in the suburbs of Lincoln, Neb. He jokes it would be more alarming if he were also wearing a kilt, the standard uniform of the Highland Games, while tossing a round 16-pound weight attached to a long handle.

The Highland Games are built around classic Scottish Highland sports, or “heavy events” such as the hammer toss and caber toss, an event where competitors lift a full-length log upright, run with it and toss it as straight as possible so it flips end-over-end. “The neighbors are lucky I don’t own a caber yet,” he says.

Mr. Kasson, who is 6-foot-4 and weighs 285 pounds, competed in amateur Strongman competitions in his 20s. “Essentially you’re picking up or moving ridiculously heavy stuff,” he says.

Just as his Strongman career was ending, a friend told him about the Highlander, a competition founded in Scotland comprised of Strongman events and Highland Games events.

Mr. Kasson throws a weight for distance in the 2018 Scottish Highland Gathering & Games in Pleasanton, Calif. Photo: Douglass Fletcher Sisk

After participating in his first Highlander competition in 2011, he began entering Scottish Highland Games competitions. A centuries-old Scottish tradition, the games are now held throughout the world. Many competitors, including Mr. Kasson, have no Scottish heritage.

“Strongman competitors are so serious to the point the events aren’t fun,” he says. As for his newer sport: “It’s a bunch of guys in kilts throwing sticks and stones in a field, so you really can’t take yourself too seriously. It’s more like a party.”

The 33-year-old turned pro in 2014 and competes in up to 18 events a year. He says he’s made just over $5,000 in prize money this year: “My wife wouldn’t let me do this if I wasn’t getting paid.” Mr. Kasson also works full time as a physical therapist in Lincoln, which comes in handy considering he’s suffered ACL and MCL injuries and kneecap dislocations over the years.

“The Highland Games work explosive power and speed rather than raw strength, so the events are easier on my knees,” he says. But given the injury risk, he considers himself lucky to have access to rehab facilities.

He is the reigning Highland Games Heavy Events world champion and will defend his title at the New Hampshire Highland Games & Festival, Sept 20 to 22 in Lincoln, N.H.

Mr. Kasson warms up for a light weight for distance throw with 28 pounds. He says body mechanics is key to efficient throwing. VIDEO: Dana Damewood for The Wall Street Journal

The Workout

Mr. Kasson’s training consists of nine 90-minute sessions a week. He doubles up on Saturdays, Sundays and Tuesdays and takes one rest day. Training consists of a warm-up, 20 to 40 training throws, then another 10 to 20 focused throws, then gym work, followed by a cool-down with foam rolling and a cold-tub session.

Early in the season, he tries to get as strong as possible, performing dead lifts, squats, bench and overhead presses and Olympic lifts like the snatch or clean and jerk. He drastically changed his training this year to focus more on throwing leading into the season.

“It’s really monotonous,” he says. “I’m throwing 150 to 200 reps a week in all of my disciplines combined.” His strength sessions focus more on how fast he can move the weight versus how much weight he can get up. Given that his events entail hurling heavy objects, “it’s all about being explosive and getting as much power as you can, as quickly as possible,” he says.

Mr. Kasson studies videos to break down the biomechanics of throwing techniques. “You need to know when to apply force or when to be relaxed and let things flow,” he says. “There’s a real yin and yang to it.” He typically competes in eight events: a standing stone put and open stone throw (think shot put), light (28-pound) and heavy (56-pound) weight throws for distance, light (16-pound) and heavy (22-pound) hammer toss, the caber toss, and weight for height. That’s where the athlete tosses a 56-pound weight with one hand over a crossbar.

Mr. Kasson has suffered knee injuries from lifting heavy weights. When training in his home gym, he now focuses on explosive speed rather than the amount of weight. Photo: Dana Damewood for The Wall Street Journal

The Diet

Mr. Kasson works with a sports dietitian to fine-tune his 5,000 to 6,000 calorie-a-day diet. He tries to eat every three hours. His hearty breakfast includes a bagel, four eggs, smoked salmon and spinach. Lunch is usually leftovers from dinner: a lean protein and carbs. But if someone brings in burgers and malts to the office, he occasionally indulges. He consumes at least two protein shakes throughout the day. Dinner might be grilled chicken thighs over salad with mashed potatoes and steamed carrots. His splurge is cake doughnuts.

The Gear and Cost

Mr. Kasson estimates he invested $3,000 on his home gym equipment, which includes a power rack, about 1,000 pounds of plates, various bars, dumbbells, kettlebells weighing up to 203 pounds and medicine balls. He also has hammers, shot puts and stones.

“My kilt is a far cry from the traditional dress—a kilt made of 8 yards of fabric,” he says. “The guys who throw in them look great, but they are super heavy.” Mr. Kasson sticks to a bare-bones, $60-$70 kilt and long-sleeved top that protects him from the sun. He wears Adidas javelin shoes.

For the hammer throw, he bolts blades onto the bottom of steel-toed work boots. Gloves aren’t allowed in the games, so he uses a mixture of pine gum rosin and turpentine on his hands to make sure his hammer doesn’t slide from his grip.

He uses a Whoop strap fitness tracker, mostly to ensure he’s getting eight hours of sleep ($28 a month). He wears braces on his knees for training and competitions.

The Playlist

Mr. Kasson’s guilty gym pleasure is dubstep, a club sound known for its distinctive bass line and refracted rhythms. “I just like the beat,” he says. “The only time I listen to it is in the gym.”

Training After an ACL Injury

About 250,000 people suffer from anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) injuries each year in the U.S., according to the University of North Carolina Injury Prevention Research Center.

The ACL is an important stabilizer in the knee. After an injury, cross-training is key to becoming strong and active again, says Deena Poll Goodman, a physical therapist and owner of Goodman Physical Therapy in Los Angeles.

“Oftentimes we strengthen muscles that are already strong, like the quads, to get them stronger, and forget about the smaller muscles or muscles on the opposite side of that body part,” she says. “For example, hamstring length and strength is just as important to the knee as spine mobility and back strength.”

A rehab program should start with lighter weights and stretching, she says. “The concept of supporting the joints above and below the knee—the ankle and the hip—is important when training to maintain balance and not cause strain,” Ms. Goodman says.

She suggests incorporating swimming or pool exercises, band exercises to strengthen hips and outer thighs and Pilates-based reformer or mat exercises for trunk stability into a routine. She says standing on a half foam roller can help increase the firing of the joint and muscles in the knee.

description: A former Strongman competitor trains nine times a week to be his best at events where he tosses heavy stones and logs.
